brief_summary.textblock:
Treatments for the macroscopic or pathologic lesions caused by HPV infection can be
      classified as topical, surgical, destructive, or immunomodulatory. Post surgical treatments
      generally consist of analgesic, anti-inflammatory and topical antimicrobial agents to reduce
      the risk of local infections.

      The aim of this study is to compare the efficacy and safety of polyhexamethylene
      biguanide-based vaginal suppositories to a similar chlorhexidine-based treatment, in the
      post recovery regimen after surgical treatment of cervical lesions.

      Women who underwent to CO2 laser therapy for cervical lesions are randomly assigned to
      receive 10 days of antiseptic treatment with chlorhexidine digluconate vaginal
      suppositories, or polyhexamethylene biguanide vaginal suppositories (Monogin® / BiguanelleTM
      vaginal suppositories, Lo.Li.Pharma, Italy). A weekly follow-up check was performed for 6
      weeks.

clinical_study.brief_title: Antisepsis Regimen in the Surgical Treatment of Human Papilloma Virus Generated Cervical Lesions: Polyhexamethylene Biguanide Versus Chlorhexidine
clinical_study.condition: Antisepsis Regimen After Surgical Treatment of HPV Infected Lesions

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  positive colposcopy examination

          -  positive Papanicolaou smear

          -  pathological biopsy

          -  physical ablation by CO2 laser therapy for a number of lesions included between 3 and
             5

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  pregnancy

primary_outcome.description: Diagnosis of eventual bacterial infection is performed according to Amsel's criteria
primary_outcome.time_frame: After three weeks by the day of the laser treatment

primary_outcome.description: Visual scoring was assessed depending on the grade of the defect (from 1 to 3)
primary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline bleeding at 6 weeks
primary_outcome.time_frame: At weekly intervals by the day of laser treatment

primary_outcome.description: Visual scoring for healing is assessed depending on the grade of the defect (from 1 to 3)
primary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline healing process at 6 weeks
primary_outcome.time_frame: At weekly intervals by the day of laser treatment

primary_outcome.description: Visual scoring for irritation is assessed depending on the grade of the defect (from 1 to 3)
primary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline irritation status at 6 weeks
primary_outcome.time_frame: At weekly intervals by the day of laser treatment

primary_outcome.description: Diagnosis is performed according to the Amsel's criteria
primary_outcome.time_frame: After six weeks by the day of laser treatment

reference.citation: Wiley DJ, Douglas J, Beutner K, Cox T, Fife K, Moscicki AB, Fukumoto L. External genital warts: diagnosis, treatment, and prevention. Clin Infect Dis. 2002 Oct 15;35(Suppl 2):S210-24.
Kaehn K. Polihexanide: a safe and highly effective biocide. Skin Pharmacol Physiol. 2010;23 Suppl:7-16. Epub 2010 Sep 8. Review.

Koburger T, Hübner NO, Braun M, Siebert J, Kramer A. Standardized comparison of antiseptic efficacy of triclosan, PVP-iodine, octenidine dihydrochloride, polyhexanide and chlorhexidine digluconate. J Antimicrob Chemother. 2010 Aug;65(8):1712-9. Epub 2010 Jun 15.

Müller G, Kramer A. Biocompatibility index of antiseptic agents by parallel assessment of antimicrobial activity and cellular cytotoxicity. J Antimicrob Chemother. 2008 Jun;61(6):1281-7. Epub 2008 Mar 25.
